resources.string: π ≈ 4 × points in circle / total points

Take a circle with a radius of 1 and a square with a side length of 1. The area of the circle will be π, and the area of the square will be 1. Center the circle and the square on the origin of a graph and look at quadrant I. You will see the illustration shown when you open the app. As you pick random points within this area, you will get closer and closer to filling the entire space. By picking these points, you are slowly approximating the area of the circle and the square. Since we know that the circle's area is π and the square's area is 1, dividing the amount of points in the circle by the total amount of points will give you a value close to π. Since we are only looking at a quarter of the entire graph, we must multiply this fraction by 4 in order to find our estimated value of π.

This app uses the Random.org API. The user inputs a number of points between 1 and 10000, each point needing two decimal values between 0 and 1. The app sends a POST request to the API in order to receive a JSON response of the needed values. If the user wants 10 points, the app will ask for 20 decimals. These decimals are then converted into a coordinate position to draw the points on the screen. They are also plugged into the distance formula to find out if the point is inside the circle.
